chapter.pericope: God’s Full and Final Revelation in the Son
chapter.p: 1 Although﻿*Here “although” is supplied as a component of the participle (“spoke”) which is understood as concessive God spoke long ago in many partsOr “portions” and in many ways to the fathers by the prophets, 2in these last days he has spoken to us by a Son, whom he appointed heir of all things, through whom also he made the world,Or “the universe”; literally “the ages” 3who is the radiance of his glory and the representation of his essence, sustaining all things by the word of power.Some manuscripts have “by the word of his power. When he had made purification for sins, he sat down” When he﻿*Here “when” is supplied as a component of the participle (“had made”) which is understood as temporal had made purification for sins through him, he sat down at the right hand of the Majesty on high, 4having become by so much better than the angels, by as much as he has inherited a more excellent name than theirs.
chapter.pericope: The Son Superior to the Angels
chapter.p: 5For to which of the angels did he ever say,

ul.li2: today I have begotten you,”A quotation from Ps 2:7

ul.li1: “I will be his fatherLiterally “to him for a father”,
ul.li2: and he will be my sonLiterally “to me for a son””?A quotation from 2 Sam 7:14 (cf. 1 Chr 17:13)

chapter.p: 6And again, when he brings the firstborn into the world, he says,

ul.li1: “And let all the angels of God worship him.”A quotation from Deut 32:43 and Ps 97:7
“The one who makes his angels winds,
and his servants a flame of fire,”A quotation from Ps 104:4
“Your throne, O God, is forever and everLiterally “for the age of the age”,
and the scepter of righteous is the scepter of your kingdom.
ul.li2: 9You have loved righteousness and hated lawlessness;
ul.li1: because of this God, your God, has anointed you
ul.li2: with the olive oil of joy more than your companions.A quotation from Ps 45:6–7

ul.li1: “You, Lord, laid the foundation of the earth in the beginning,
and the heavens are the works of your hands;
ul.li2: and they will all become old like a garment,
ul.li1: 12and like a robe you will roll them up,
and like a garment they will be changed;
but you are the same, and your years will not run out.”A quotation from Ps 102:25–27

chapter.p: 13But to which of the angels has he ever said,

ul.li1: until I make your enemies a footstool for your feet.”A quotation from Ps 110:1

chapter.p: 14Are they not all spirits engaged in special service, sent on assignment for the sake of those who are going to inherit salvation?
